name: Writing and Remembering: A Memoir Workshop

section.name: Writing and Remembering: A Memoir Workshop

values.comments:
A workshop course in the writing of expository prose.  Assignments include informal as well as formal essays, covering such topics as autobiography, family history, review, interview, analysis of advertising and popular culture, travel, work, and satire.

	Students unanimously regarded Creative Non-Fiction Writing as an excellent, enjoyable course.  One student described it as “fulfilling, energetic and intellectually stimulating” and another described it as “nothing short of fabulous.”  The class was described as having a strong “sense of community” which in turn “made for strong workshops and peer feedback.”  Just one student reported wishing more time had been spent discussing “what a memoir is and evaluating the texts read within that form.”

	Professor Watterson was praised by students, who described her variably as a “valuable asset to the UPenn community” and the “epitome of an educator.”  Students judged Professor Watterson to be good at creating “a safe and open space for writers” and described her as “challenging [them] to sharpen [their] words and stories.”

	One student reported that while the course “demanded a great deal of writing, it was allocated in measured doses” such that creating a portfolio was a manageable task.  This review was based on eight student comments.
